awd_titl_txt: CSBR:  Living Stocks:   The Escherichia Coli Genetic Stock Center
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will contribute to the operation of the E. coli Genetic Stock Center (CGSC) at Yale University. Escherichia coli is an important model organism and is arguably the most completely understood cellular organism from a genetics and biochemistry standpoint. This high degree of understanding has made E. coli not just an important subject of research, but also the laboratory workhorse for studying a broad variety of organisms as well as an invaluable tool for biotechnology. The mission of the CGSC is to act as a central repository for genetically modified strains of E. coli created by the research community, so that they may be readily available to other researchers and educators. To that end, the CGSC maintains a collection of about 28,000 cultures of genetically defined derivatives of E. coli K-12. There are over 8,000 different mutations represented in this strain collection with verified mutations in over 90% of the 4,111 identified genes in the sequenced E. coli K-12 genome. These cultures are distributed to researchers and educators throughout the US and in over 65 countries worldwide. In addition to the distribution of cultures, the CGSC is also an information resource, and provides information about strains, mutations, genes, gene products and genetic maps, in a fully searchable database on the web. Importantly CGSC also acts as a source of expert information and advice for those researchers who have questions about using the E. coli strains in the collection. 

The CGSC will continue to maintain and expand its publicly available database on strain genotypes, phenotypes, histories and pedigrees, which is unique to the Stock Center. The information systems will be enhanced to increase compatibility with other E. coli web resources, including the EcoliWiki project, EcoGene and EcoCyc. The CGSC is collaborating with other US culture collections and the World Data Centre for Microorganisms (WDCM) so that the collection can be indexed by global strain databases and to create a national microbial strain database. Over the period of this award, capabilities for our new strain construction services will be expanded for those users who require a genetically modified strain, but lack the capability of constructing it themselves, particularly to those outside of the traditional bacterial genetics community. This is a service unique to the CGSC and has shown great growth potential.  Access to the strain collection database, including genotypes, gene function and map location, as well as an extensive bibliography are available online (cgsc.biology.yale.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supports the E. coli Genetic Stock Center (CGSC) at Yale University. The mission of the CGSC is to act as a central repository for genetically modified laboratory strains of E. colicreated by the research community, so that they may be readily available to other researchers and educators.  Escherichia coli is an important model organism and is perhaps the best understood cellular organism from a genetics and biochemistry standpoint. This high degree of understanding has made E. coli not just an important subject of research, but also the laboratory workhorse for studying a broad variety of organisms as well as an invaluable tool for biotechnology. 

To fulfill our mission, the CGSC maintains a collection of ~28,000 cultures of genetically defined derivatives of E. coli K-12. There are over 8,000 different mutations represented in this strain collection with verified mutations in over 90% of the 4,111 identified genes in the sequenced E. coli K-12 genome. The CGSC also has begun to maintain and distribute a collection of bacteriophage that are useful in the genetic manipulation and research on the evolution and ecology of E. coli.

These cultures are distributed to researchers and educators in the US and over 65 countries worldwide. In addition to the distribution of cultures, the CGSC is also an information resource, and provides information about strains, mutations, genes, gene products and genetic maps, in a fully searchable internet database.  Our database is integrated with other E. coli web resources, including the EcoliWiki project and EcoCyc.  Access to the strain collection database, including genotypes, gene function and map location, as well as an extensive bibliography are available at (http://cgsc.biology.yale.edu/). 

The CGSC also acts as a source of expert information and advice for those researchers who have questions about using the E. coli strains in our collection. This has become increasingly important as our user base has expanded beyond the traditional bacterial genetics community. To help serve our expanded user community, the CGSC has started offering strain construction services for those users who require a genetically modified strain, but lack the capability of constructing it themselves.

As an indication of the relevance and utility of the CGSC to the research community, over the 3 years covered by this grant, researchers have used strains from the CGSC, for on average, over 350 scientific publications and 75 patents per year.

 


Last Modified: 01/13/2022
Modified by: John E Wertz
